FRIDAY, APRIL 14, 1905..
Cairo Drainage.
The settlement of the Cairo drainage scheme has been postponed until after the holidays.
Denishwal
The petitions for the release of the Denshawai criminals have been sent to Vienna to the Khedive.
Contraventions.
During the last twenty four hours six thefts, twenty various offences and 57 contraventions were reported.
Cairo Ciroulating Library.
Up to the 30th September the above Library will be open at the following hours: Morning, 9.30 to 11, Evening, 5.30 to 7.
Abbassleh Military School.
The tender of Ashmaoui Effendi Mustafa for the construction of a Military School at Abassieh at a cost of L.E. 14,941 Mills. 535 has been accepted.
Suspected Plague Case.

The Director of the Quarantine Department has reported that the suspected case of plague diserabarked from S.S. "Trifels" at Suez has proved to be non-infectious and the bacteriological examination has negatived the diagnosis of plague.
Public Works Department.

By a service order of 24th June last Mohamed Eff. Gawad has been appointed provisionally as engineer of the 5th Circle of Irrigation. Habib Abdel Melik, not having fulfilled the requirements of the service, has been requested to resign.
Egypt and Bulgaria.

The Bulgarian Commercial Agent at Alexandria has sent a report to the Bulgarian minister of foreign affairs in which he gives a list of the Bulgarian goods likely to find a market in Egypt. These products are as follows, wheat or maize flour, all cereals principally corn, barley, rice, peas beans, potatoes, dry fruits, cattle large and small, butter fresh or salt, cheese, honey, tobacco, firewood, coal, carpets etc.
The French Fete.

Mr. de Valdrome will preside on the occasion of the celebration of the 14th July in the Esbekieh Garden. Those desiring to take part in the ceremony are requested to, communicate with the secretary of the French Club. The committee of organisation offer their best. thanks for the numerous con- tributions received up to the present and announce that further gifts may be sent up to the 13th instant. It is announced that invitations will be issued to representatives of the native Press.
Burglars at Khartoum,

A store in the neighbourhood of the flourmill at Khartoum was entered, a few days ago, by burglars and a part of its stock was removed. The burglars, we understand, have been traced and arrested. A private house near Victoria School was entered last Friday night through an open window and the pockets of the occupant were relieved of a considerable sum of money. It is hoped that the energy manifested by the local authorities a few months ago in tracing and bringing to justice a gang of thieves may be put forth at present in order to put a stop to these burglaries before they become rife.
Shortage of Cotton Yarn.

The continued scarcity of cotton yarn and the high prices charged tor same are having a somewhat serious effect upon the spinning trade in Lancashire. In order to relieve the scarcity the Central Council of the North East Lancashire Cotton Spinners and Manufacturers' Association, at a meeting held last week, decided in favour of a fortnight's stoppage of the mills on dates between the end of June and the end of September. If the whole of the local associations affiliated with the central organisation adopt the recommendation indicated above, 500,000 looms and 150,000 workpeople will be affected. This would represent a reduced absorption of yarn of approximately 30,000lbs, or equal to two month's exports to foreign countries. *

div.head:
CASSA DI SCONTO.
LONDON OPINION.
THIS MORNING'S MEETING.
div.p: The affairs of the Cassa di Sconto e di Risparmio are progressing favourably and there is a prospect of reopening and the discharging of current liabilities. The bank may wind up voluntarily within a moderate period without material loss and the position is decidedly better than was feared. Influential parties have provided the necessary funds for the immediate pressing needs.

The meeting of the shareholders was summoned for 10 o'clock this morning at the Alexandria office of the Cassa di Sconto. Punctually at 10 o'clock the door was placed ajar so as to allow only one person to enter at a time. A cavass was stationed at the entrance and took the proxy of each person. Unfortunately the bank did not take the precaution to get the "feuille de présence" signed by all the shareholders who entered, and afterwards the room was so crowded it was found impossible to obtain the signatures. After a calculation it was estimated that sixty five thousand shares were represented. According to the statutes a quorum can only be obtained with seventy five thousand shares, and as ten thousand shares were lacking, the chairman of the board of directors, the advocate Clemente Castro, announced that the meeting could not therefore officially take place. He then read the "ordre du jour" and asked if any shareholders wished to put any questionsas the board of directors were willing to reply. Some shareholders then proceeded to make observations and M. Metaxa rose to reply. He stated that a group had been formed with the assistance of the National Bank of Egypt, who were willing to advance the necessary funds, about £300,000, on the condition that a friendly liquidation should be agreed to by the meeting. A shareholder then asked if he were confident of the success of these negotiations. Mr. Metaxa answered that it there had been a quorum and the meeting had been officially constituted, he believed that the arrangement could have been arrived at today. As the present assembly could not be considered valid and as according to the law a second convocation could not be made until an interval of ten days had elapsed, and, furthermore, as it was vitally necessary to come to a decision before the 5th inst., by which date the bank must either reopen its doors or go into liquidation, therefore it was moved by by Mr. Edgar Suares, that the present meeting should go on permanently until 4 o'clock this afternoon, by which time seventy five thousand shares would, it was hoped, be re- presented and the necessary quorum obtained. This proposition was carried unanimously as it was recognised to be the only way out the of the difficulty. The shareholders who have not yet signed the "feuille de présence" will assemble at 3 p.m. to append their names and the meeting will be resumed at 4 p.m.
All the directors of the bank were present including :-

Castro Clemente, Chairman, Cav. Grisante Vannucci, Managing Director, and the members of the board, Jacques Barda, of S.R.Barda e Figli, Sigismund Behrend, of Behrend & Co. Paul Bless, of P. Bless & Co., Karam Emin, of the Commercial & Estates Company of Egypt, Late S. Karam & Frères, Emilio Lombardo, of the Navigazione Generale Italiana, Cav. Giorgio Metaxa, of the Union Bank, Vienna, Enrico Nahman, of Rolo Figli & Co., Cav. Giacomo Rimini, of the Union Bank at Trieste, Halifa Sachs, of Halifa Sachs & Fils, Cav. The meeting was very tranquil and the shareholders appeared to face the situation with a calm state of mind. It is considered from the attitude of the meeting this morning, that the shareholders will approve the project of the board and thus after the meeting the desired arrangement will be arrived at.

div.head:
THE "EGYPTIAN STANDARD".
INNACURACIES AND DISTORTIONS.
div.p: The recent comments of our comic contemporary, the "Egyptian Standard," on the plague have aroused considerable amusement in London, The "Pall Mall Gazette" remarks:---

The "Egyptian Standard," the newly-founded organ of the amiable Mustapha Kamel Pasha, reaches us periodically from Cairo, and is wont to afford us instruction not unmingled with amusement. To-day we learn that a recent slight increase in bubonic plague in Upper Egypt has inspired that journal to announce that 338 deaths from plague were reported for the week ending June 10, and to suggest that "it is the Government's wish gradually to eradicate the native-born inhabitants from Egyptian soil following the praiseworthy methods employed by the Anglo-Americans with the Red Indians in the United States." But the joke is that (as the "Times" correspondent states) "the 338 deaths reported were those of cattle and buffaloes, caused by bovine typhus." Really, Mus'apha Kamel's Editor is what you might call a Whole Hogger, and no mistake. His capacity for wholesale fiction should secure him a lucrative position on the staff of some seditious native journal in Bengal, if ever he succeeds in making Egypt too hot him-which, we rather fancy, it is just possible he may. The "St. James's Gazette" says:-

That great and good servant of his Suzerain, Mustapha Pasha Kamel, has for long, like young Copperfield, been "a-going it." But we doubt whether his organ, the "Egyptian Standard" will surpass the splendour of its latest outburst. Commenting on the "fact" that 338 deaths from plague were reported for the week ended June 10, it calls on the Government to check this terrible mortality "unless, of course, it is the Govern ment's wish gradually to eradicate the native born inhabitants from Egyptian soil following the praiseworthy methods employed by the Anglo-Americans with the Red Indians in the United States." Unluckily just when, despite the odd use of the word "praise worthy," we were beginning to shrivel with horrified shame for these more than Machiavellian designs of the usurping tyrant (us), we read in the "Times" message from Cairo that these 338 deaths were those of cattle and buffaloes caused by bovine typhus. This is the most unkindest cut of all Ourselves we should never have so insulted the "native- born inhabitants"-or, the cattle and buffaloes? Mustapha Pasha Kamel must have been taking a leaf out of the book of sedition-mongers in India. Or was this paper's lucubration prompted by a study of the methods of Sinn Fein? Anyhow, he has made a bull rather than a bull's eye.

div.head: CAIRO STATION.
div.p: Some time ago we published a letter from a correspondent pointing out the necessity for the establishment of a first-class refreshment room in Cairo station and our correspondent's Iviews were subsequently endorsed in a leading article which appeared in the columns of a Cairo contemporary. It is now rumoured that a new contract of three years' duration has been granted by the Administration to the proprietor of the café on the station platform. It is difficult to understand why Alexandria, Tantah, and other stations should have firstclass refreshment rooms, while all that Cairo station can boast of is a very second rate caté, where it is impossible to procure a good cup of tea or French coffee, not to mention luncheon or dinner. Were the State Railways transformed into a Company the directors would ap preciate the needs of the public in the interests of their shareholders, for with capable management such an undertaking should prove very remunerative. Travelling in Egypt, especially in the summer, is sufficiently trying and its discomforts should be alleviated by every possible means. We trust the Administration will further inquire into the circumstances in which the public is to be deprived, during three years, of the comforts of a respectable refreshment room at the Cairo terminus, for to the uninitiated the reason remains profoundly obscure.

div.head: A PEEP AT CYPRUS.
A GARDEN ISLAND.
div.p: There has been much talk at home of garden cities. In Nicosia there is one ready-made. Within the circle of its Venetian ramparts there are groves of stately palms, feathery mimosas, sweet-scented Persian lilacs, and the bright glossy green of oranges and lemons starred with odorous blossoms. Houses occur as accidents in the mass of foliage. Walking in the narrow, winding streets, you wonder what has become of the trees until an open doorway reveals the spacious garden court overflowing with foliage, the tender hue of the vine mingling with the darker tints of the fig and relieved by the vivid scarlet of the pomegranate blooms. This is all within the walls. Outside there is the moat planted with eucalyptus which have attained the dimensions of forest trees, and, beyond, the roads lined with pines and the English bungalows smothered with roses and passion flowers. One may see the same thing elsewhere, but the gardens inside the city are unique. It would be safe to say that there are more flowers to the square mile than in any other city in the world. There is a street of cobblers, and every stall has its roof of vine. There is a street of blacksmiths, but even there the intruding green softens the sward hue of the forges.

The road from Larnaca is dull. Why Lamaca should be the chief port is not apparent. It is an open roadstead, and the town is in the midst of the least fertile portion of the island. On the other hand, Famagusta has a harbour with a quay 800 feet long and a depth of 24 feet of water alongside. It is connected with Nicosia by an excellent light railway traversing the richest grain district in Cyprus. They are getting in their harvest now, and the journey of 37 miles presents a succession of delightfal rural pictures. There is a gay note of colour in the Cypriote dress, both of men and women and the Messaoria plain is a sheet of gold diapered with patches of a lighter tint where the wheat and barley have fallen beneath the sickle. Famagusta itself is inhabited exclusively by Turks. They seem to live mainly by frequenting one another's cafes, and fill up their time between dawn and dusk by smoking nargilehs Outside the walls is the Greek town of Varosia. Here people work. Shoemakers, tailors, bakers, and shopkeepers ply their trades briskly, and here are the women shaping the pottery that has a reputation in the island and is modelled on forms which have obtained since the days when the heap of stones called Salomis was a city. Varosia stands for the modern Famagusta. Near the station is the Savoy Hotel, between which and the club the half dozen Englishmen whose work lies here divide their hours of leisure ; all except one—the harbour-master. He is planted among the Turks in a part of the fortifications known as Othello's Tower. There was, it seems, a Pro- veditore of the Signory of Venice here named Cristoforo Moro, though whether it was the original of Othello is not clear. But Shakespeare, from act ii, to act v., laid his scene at. Famagusta, and the worthy skipper is proud of his residence. He has turned the grim Venetian stronghold into a comfortable English home.

The city has undergone the shrinkage which marks every seat of former civilisation into which the Ottoman has stepped. There are vast waste spaces and the remains of thirty churches and several jmlaces. The Royal residence is now a police barracks and a prison containing pyramids of old stone, round shot, and queer pieces of artillery of the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries. The chief glory of the place is the Cathedral, now a mosque, and the strangest mosque, surely, in which a Mussulman ever prayed. It is a noble work of the early fourteenth century—pure French Gothic, with two western towers and a glorious apse with flying buttresses reminding one of Notre Dame. It is only by looking at the palm trees that we realise that we are not in some old cathedral town of the West. Here in the days of Famagusta's splendour the kings of Cyprus were crowned kings of Jerusalem, and here opposite the west front, in the last dreadfifl days of 1571, the brave defender of the fortress, Bragadino, was flayed alive while the statues of the saints were being dragged from these now empty niches and the Christian fane was being turned into a mosque. He had been lured into surrender by the infamous Mustafa under the promise took place in 1821. There are about 51,000 Turks in the island now. They are a quiet, inoffensive section of the population, but the land is slowly passing out of their hands into those of the more industrious Christian cultivators. They prefer employment under the Cyprus Government I found one reading a sixpenny edition of an English classic the other day; to one who knows anything of the Turks the incident was amazing. Not less so is the fact that, in addition to a high school for boys, they have another for girls, built chiefly by subscriptions from Moslems in Nicosia as a memorial to Queen Victoria.

We were on our way to the ruins of an ancient castle near Kyrenia a magnificent eagle sailed close overhead. "Aetos I" exclaimed the Greek boy who was our guide. He spoke the tongue of Homer, of whom he had never heard. The word took us away from the vestiges of mediaeval Cyprus and set us thinking of the many masters whom the island has known in its chequered history. It is tranquil under the present one. It might be more prosperous, but in contrast with what we had seen of late it is an Eden, and to the traveller fresh from Ottoman territory a delightful resting-place. ("Manchester Guardian")

div.p: The following is text of the letter addressed to the Minister of Public Instruction by the late Director of the Khedivial School of Law.

Vous m'avez fait parvenir une petition par laquelle un certain nombre de jeunes gens sor- tant de l'enseignement secondaire vous de- mandent de faire ritablir £ l'Ecole de Droit les cours du soir. Cette experience a ete desastreuse. Je conserve dans les archives de mon secretariat la oopie d'une serie de rapports des presidents de commissions d'examen de fin d'annee qui tous cons- tatent l'insuffisance de preparation des aspirants £ la licence ayant frequents exclusive- ment les cours du soir.

"J'ai pu constater que la valeur des etudiants frequentant les cours du soir, et specialement de ceux de premiere et de seconde annee, est de beaucoup inferieure k celle de leurs condisciples des cours du jour. Sir Malcolm Mcllwraith enregistrait, £ son tour, au lendemain de sa premiere visite a l'Ecole, les monies risultats decourageants, et je detache de son rapport sur les examens de 1898 un fragment qui montre assez ce qu'ont ete dans le passe les cours du soir et ce qa'ils seraient destines £ redevenir en cas de rita- blissement:—

"J'ai constate £ tous les examens auxquels j'aiassiste, que les ei&ves qui etaientnotablement inferieurs £ la moyenne, etaient toujours des efeves des cours du soir qui, etant gendrale- ment occopes dans la journee, ne peuvent pro- bablement pas consacrer un temps suffisant £ la preparation de leurs examens. Certes, il est tris meritoire que des jeunes gens qui sont forces de gagner leur vie en travaillant dans les Minist£res et ailleure dans la journee, con- sacrent leurs loisirs du soir £ l'acquisition de connaissances juridiques. div.p: CRICKET.
ROYAL GARRISON ARTILLERY
versus
KS.R. INSTITUTE.

The second meeting of these clubs took place at Guezireh Badrane on Friday 28th. The Institute were unable to put a full team into the field, the absentees including W.B. Davies; the captain, P.G. Windsor, who officiated in his absence, won the toss and took out Eevd. J.T. Bums with him to bat. Just after doubles figures had been passed Revd. Bums got his foot in front of a straight one from Barnes. With the exception of Windsor the Institute batsmen failed to make any resistance against Barnes and Girton both of whom bowled exceptionally well. The total amounted to 61. The Gunners made anything but a promising start, Bradley being smartly taken behind the wicket when 2. On Sullivan and Burgess being partnered runs came quickly. Both men gave easy chances at the commencement of their innings but both were fortunate to be let off, and these mistakes cost the Institute the game. The home team's total was passed with five wickets down but the later men added only 16. The Gunners who reached 80 thus won by 19 runs and avenged their defeat by 158 earlier in the season.
